definition[0]: a small animal with four legs that people often keep as a pet
definition[1]: a large animal such as a lion or tiger
example[1]: Lucy had a horse and a pet cat of her own.
example[2]: People have kept domestic cats for thousands of years.
example[4]: I've always wanted a ginger cat.
example[5]: The small fishing village was full of feral cats.
example[6]: He found a stray cat and started feeding it.
example[7]: The African wild cat is bigger than ordinary domestic cats.
example[8]: All 36 species of big cat are vulnerable or endangered.
example[9]: The cat was miaowing outside the door.
example[10]: The cat purred as she stroked it.
example[12]: If a cat gets angry, it may scratch you with its claws.
example[13]: Then the cat leapt up into the tree.
example[14]: The cat was hiding, waiting to pounce on the bird.
example[15]: We always had a cat when I was young.
example[16]: She comes in while we're away to feed the cat.
example[17]: Our cat won't let you stroke it.
example[18]: He bought some cans of cat food.
example[19]: You should change cat litter daily.
example[20]: The cat was getting too fat to fit through the cat flap.
example[21]: It is estimated that around 64 million Americans are cat owners.
example[22]: Can you let the cat out?
definition[2]: in the past, the British Government guide to standards for the Individual Saving Accounts (ISA ) introduced in 1999. It stands for reasonable Cost, easy Access, decent Terms. CAT was replaced by stakeholder ISAs in 2005.
